text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Not, not that there was anything different before or after. So, uh, the two drugs, about sixty plus percent of men respond overall. So that’s what I said. About two-thirds of the guys respond, and then one-third seems to have a long response, and one-third has a shorter response, and one-third don’t. Uh, in terms of how to pick which one of those two. Uh, for a while, I, I was picking Zytiga instead of Xtandi. Zytiga, the one complication with Zytiga, is you have to take a small dose of prednisone with it, uh, to kind of counterbalance how Zytiga works. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, the one reason we would do that is because we had some trials, uh, that were after Zytiga. But the other reason was a tendency of less fatigue with the Zytiga than the Xtandi, in my experience. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Both drugs can cause fatigue. But it seems to be more common and often a little bit worse with Xtandi. So, uh, in my choosing those two, I have been choosing Zytiga, just for that reason. Uh, but the Xtandi is a little bit easier, because you just have to take Xtandi. You don’t have to take another drug. Patient: Right. Family Member: Why are you taking prednisone with it? Patient: So Doctor: So the Zytiga, so the way Xtandi works is, if you think that we talked before about the, the testosterone has to get into the cell and do stuff. It has to bind in something in the cell called receptors. So the best way to think about it is a ball and glove. Xtandi kind of, if, if the ball is testosterone, Xtandi looks like an orange. And so it gets in the glove, and it blocks the ball. It can’t get in there. Uh, Zytiga works in a different way. It blocks the enzymes that the body uses to make testosterone. So there’s all these different precursors. So start with cholesterol, and it goes through about ten steps, and ends at testosterone. When you block it, there’s some hormones that build up that can affect the kidney. Patient: Hum. Doctor: And those hormones can affect how you handle water and potassium.

text: Patient: Yeah! You told me he talked to you. Doctor: I know. Patient: You say. Doctor: So, I said, I know you. That if we did that and everything else, you would just sort of give up. You’d be like, “I’m done. I can just barely -- my quality of life is here.” But I have to tell you, if you really needed it. One, I think your quality of life would actually be much better because you’d be so symptomatic from that problem, you couldn’t ride your bike. You couldn’t go around the block. You couldn’t do anything! You’d just be soiling yourself constantly! So, if that came to be the issue, you would want it done just to improve your quality of life. Patient: Okay. Listen. Doctor: But I also know that that’s not something you would do proactively because the thought of having a bag scares the heck out of you. I know that. I got it. And now I just threw in two possible bags that’s even more frightening. So, I need you to focus on what we have to do next. We gotta get some systemic stuff swirling through your bloodstream – Patient: Okay, but -- Doctor: To get control. We’re fixing it here, but the rest of you is not controlled. Doctor: Okay? Hi!!! Patient: So. So. Doctor: We’re having all sorts of discussion! Healthcare Professional 2: Really?

text: Patient: So you would just give up on the Xtandi and just go with the PARP inhibitor? Doctor: And you know if we were going to do the Xtandi base treatment still then we would have to – I would say we need to combine it with something else and that something else could be the BET1 inhibitor. Patient: Is there a third option you said? Doctor: Well the third option is going to chemotherapy. That is definitely an option. I’m not favoring that right off the bat just now. Okay. Patient: We would do that as a last resort? Doctor: Well yeah. I mean not quite last resort. I’m not sure I want to wait (nervous laughter) Patient: What would you recommend? Doctor: Okay so my recommendation is mainly based on trying our best not to take away options from you, okay. And the way I see it if we go to Lynparza right now, this Xtandi plus BET1 inhibitor goes away as an option because you have to be on the Xtandi currently before when they can consider you for the study. So I’m leaning towards if you qualify for the study, if everything goes right then you should go with the Xtandi plus BET inhibitor the study based option first and if that doesn’t work or if it doesn’t if you’re not eligible for whatever reason, then we go to the Lynparza. I mean that is available to us as a fall back at any point. Family Member: Okay. Patient: So you’d say try the uh uh BET thing and uh if that doesn’t work go to the Lynparza which is the PARP inhibitor and continue with the Xtandi? Family Member: With, with the BET. Doctor: The Lynparza we’ll see, most likely I will stop the Xtandi at that point.

text: Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But, I I did want to speak to you about um a research study that we’re doing that I think would be a good fit for you and I wanted to give you some details about that. Patient: Mm-kay. Doctor: And then give you some time to uh look at some written information that I’ll give you to take home. And you can look at that with your sister and your great-niece and the three of you can decide together whether you think this might be good idea for you. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And um I just wanted to um write some notes down. And then after I write these notes, I’m going to give you some detailed information about the the clinical trials. So, if if you are not at J_____ H_____. If you were just seeing a medical oncologist without- private practice or community um then the next step for someone like you, where the cancer might be growing or progressing despite the Abiraterone- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But typically we want to have two options. Number one would be switching from that pill to a different pill. And the second pill is called Xtandi. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: That is also known as Enzalutamide. Got a long name. The short name is Xtandi, the long name is Enzalutamide. And this is a pill you take it every day and it’s also four pills at a time. Four pills all at once. The dose is one hundred sixty milligrams. So it’s a little bit different from the Abiraterone. And this one does not require Prednisone, no Prednisone for this one. So it’s one less thing to take. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: The second option for some patients, whose cancer is progressing more rapidly, especially in those that its causing symptoms, like bone pain for example.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So for about a month and a half you may have a hair problem. But that’s it. Patient: No long-term neuropathy or anything that? Doctor: Not, okay, so not with the four doses and uh not the way we give it because we really have tons you know of experience and we know how to give it, quite frankly. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you went to the community, they give you six doses really high, and you would end up with neuropathy that’s pretty severe. Patient: Okay, um. Is there any detriment to having the chemo before the radiation? Doctor: So we actually prefer it because we actually know how to treat your whole body systemically with all these medicines from the chemist. (whistle noise) Patient: Right. Doctor: With these medicines, but we also, and it also gives you more time to heal. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: From the surgery, which is better for you as far as long-term side effects. Family Member: Uh hum. Okay.

text: Patient: At what point would you do the scan? Is it when it goes above one? Doctor: When it goes above one. Patient: And that would be here at JH? Doctor: I would recommend that; it’s not absolutely necessary. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Typically you can do everything in one single day. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So you’d come in in the morning and you’d get your CT scan and you’d have your bone scan. And two or three hours after the two scans are done you would see me and by that time you would have the results. Have the images on my computer to look at them and discuss the results with you. The other possibility is to do the scans at a local radiology facility and then to get the images with the CDs and have the reports, get them sent to me and have one brought to you physically. But you know like I said if you agree with me, is to do it here. Patient: Yes. Doctor: If it’s not too much of a hardship. Patient: Very good. If when and needed. Doctor: Yes. And again that might not be for another six to twelve months. It could be sooner, a bit later depending on how or if your PSA increases. Patient: Oh.

text: Patient: Yes, I know, my family doctor, same thing. Doctor: Yeah. So, I think you have to sign signature of patient here, right here. Patient: Okay Alright. Doctor: So use that and then date it. That’s right. Family Member: If he does the chemo or radium Doctor: Yeah Family Member: and then a trial opens up does he just jump to the trial? Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
